text: (gentle music)
Thank you to Malika and Carolyn
for sharing your personal stories.
They're very powerful and inspiring.
I feel very honored to be part
of this year's Talented Twelve class
and I feel very privileged to be able to share
my personal story and my research work with you.
I was born in Surabaya, Indonesia.
And I developed early interest in math and science.
Here's a picture of me winning the third prize
in our national math competition in sixth grade.
And when I was 15, I was awarded a scholarship
to study in Singapore.
And I did my O Level at Anglo-Chinese School (Independent)
and my A Level at Raffles Junior College.
Some of you may have heard the Raffles brand,
famous for being one of the top feeder schools
to top colleges in the US and the UK.
And I did quite well there
and at that point I simply wanted to see
how far I can push myself in my education,
so I decided to go to the US for college.
I attended Columbia University
and at that point, I knew that I wanted to study chemistry.
I was able to secure a lab position
with Professor Ron Breslow in my first two years.
And along the way, my research interest shifted
to complex molecule synthesis,
and I joined Professor Tristan Lambert's lab
in my junior year.
During this time, there is also one watershed moment
that I think really defined my career trajectory
to get to where I am today.
I attended a Thursday night
organic chemistry problem session by Professor Tom Katz.
And during this problem session, he said,
"I really love giving problems from my own paper
because no one reads my paper."
And to me, this was the embodiment of that romantic notion
in academia where you are free to pursue
whatever problem you think is worth pursuing
without having to care what other people think of it.
And I think this was truly the first time
I really considered a career in academia.
In Spring 2007, Professor Phil Baran came to Columbia
to give a talk and he gave a really amazing talk
and he was just crushing all this natural product synthesis.
And I got a chance to talk to him a little bit
during his visit and he asked me,
"Are you going to grad school?
You should come to Scripps."
And to me, this is the equivalent of Nick Saban
recruiting you to go to Alabama to play football.
And you just don't say no to that.
So I decided to go to Scripps for my PhD.
This slide summarizes my PhD thesis work.
Here we want to have a proof of concept demonstration
that we can convert simple, readily available steroid
to more complex, highly oxidized ones.
The target we chose is ouabagenin,
which is known to be a highly potent inhibitor
of the sodium-potassium ion pump.
The question that we want to ask
is whether we can achieve this
by using a carefully choreographed C-H oxidation sequence.
The answer is, yes, we can,
but not very efficiently.
To illustrate, it took us three steps to install
a hydroxylic group at that C19 methyl position.
And I was always constantly in search
for a better solution to this problem.
I was constantly looking for a one-step solution
that can address this issue.
And while I was searching for a potential solution,
I came across this passage from Professor E. J. Corey's book
"The Logic of Chemical Synthesis".
Here he talked about how enzymatic transformations
with cytochrome P-450 can have substantial advantage
over chemical synthesis.
So I was intrigued by this idea,
and I drove up two hours north
to look for a postdoc position.
My preferred route is the I-5 to the 57
because I get to stop by The Brewery
for some nice barrel-aged Belgian beers.
And I was able to secure a postdoc position
with Professor Frances Arnold,
one of the pioneers in the field of enzyme engineering.
And I approached her with the following idea.
I wanted to subject stevioside,
which is the main component
of the artificial sweetener, Stevia,
to a series of enzymatic oxidation
to convert it to more valuable compounds,
such as xylopinic acids,
which has been reported to have anti-HIV activity.
Unfortunately, she said that she's phasing out
hydroxylation chemistry from her lab,
but she sold me on this idea of working
on new-to-nature enzymatic reaction.
And I had a lot of fun developing
new-to-nature enzymatic cyclopropanation reaction
by engineering a protein biocatalyst for carbon transfer.
In my independent career,
I wanted to combine my two trainings.
The vision is to develop new biocatalytic methods
and chemoenzymatic strategies to make complex molecules.
And this will be done by performing
both synthetic and biosynthetic studies
on complex natural products.
We view the studies to be highly synergistic
as our biosynthetic work will allow us
to identify new biocatalysts
that will then open up opportunities for enzyme engineering,
as well as application in chemoenzymatic synthesis.
And in turn, we hope that we'll be able to adapt
the results generated
for further medicinal chemistry exploration
such as analog synthesis or follow-up biological studies.
I continue to be fascinated by natural products.
These are naturally occurring small molecules
that we can isolate from natural sources.
And one of the most intriguing features of natural product
is their structural complexity.
And I think this is the reason why many people
are intrigued by natural products.
And such complexity typically arises
from scaffold tailoring through oxidations.
And in the past five years,
we've been working to develop platforms
to repurpose enzymes that are responsible
for such tailoring for application in organic chemistry.
One ongoing research direction in my lab
is the development of new biocatalysts to synthesize
noncanonical amino acid with the goal
of providing building blocks
to enable medicinal chemistry discovery.
We have been able to characterize a handful of enzymes
that can catalyze site-selective oxidation on amino acids.
And we were able to demonstrate their biocatalytic utility.
Importantly, all of these enzymes display
novel site-selectivities that are distinct
from those that are previously reported in the literature.
And we have begun to branch out
to go beyond hydroxylation chemistry.
Specifically, we're interested in the preparation
of noncanonical amino acids
that contain multiple stereocenters.
It's been shown in the literature
that such branching can dramatically alter
the properties of the resulting peptide.
So this can be potentially useful for drug discovery.
So for example,
we reported the synthesis of substituted proline derivatives
starting from the corresponding leucine derivative,
and this is done by a combination of enzymatic oxidation
and chemical reduction.
And more recently we reported the biocatalytic synthesis
of branched-chain aromatic amino acids.
And this is done by starting
from a racemic keto acid substrate.
The beta center at this keto acid is highly labile
and it can racemize readily under the reaction condition.
And the trick here is to identify an appropriate enzyme
that can only accept one of the separate enantiomer,
thereby allowing dynamic kinetic resolution
for higher diastereoselectivity and enantioselectivity
in the reaction.
Here's a more expansive story where we start
from biocatalyst discovery
and then move on to chemoenzymatic synthesis development
and followed by medicinal chemistry optimization.
The story began with the identification of an enzyme
that can catalyze hydroxylation of lysine at C4
with high efficiency.
And by using this insight,
we were able to develop a concise synthesis of cepafungin I.
As you can see here,
the enzymatic transformation is highly enabling
because it simplifies access
to the most challenging fragment of the target molecule.
And we're interested in cepafungin I
because it has been reported to be
one of the most potent inhibitor of the 20S proteasome.
This is a covalent inhibitor
where the unsaturated motif of the natural product
acts as an electrophilic warhead.
Inhibition of the proteasome has been reported
to be effective for the treatment of multiple myeloma.
And there are three drugs in the market
that act through this mechanism of action.
And we are interested in investigating
whether we can use cepafungin for the same purpose.
We collaborate with the Adibekian lab here at Scripps
to investigate the (indistinct) target specificity
of the scaffold.
And here we designed a chemical probe to achieve this goal.
The idea behind this probe is that we're gonna keep
the covalent warhead of the scaffold.
Now we're gonna equip it with an importer alkyne tag
that would allow us to identify proteins that are attacked
by this probe.
And this can be done through chemoproteomic techniques
such as in-gel fluorescence for LC-MS-MS analysis.
You can see here that we obtain a very clean gel profile,
which indicates that the compound is highly selective
for the proteasome.
And this is highly encouraging.
And based on this discovery,
we embarked on an analog synthesis
using structure-based design.
And we synthesized more than 12 analogs to date.
And gratifyingly, we were able to identify several analogs
that are more cytotoxic than the parent natural product.
And we've been able to verify this
through proteasome beta-5 inhibition assay
where the best analog that we have
now displayed about sevenfold more improvement in potency
over the parent natural product.
And more encouragingly,
we also see that compound 26 is just almost as potent
as proteasome in killing several cancer cells.
So really excited about this development
and we're intending to pursue in vivo studies
for this compound soon.
Now, at the end of the day, I'm an organic chemist,
and I want to continue to push the frontier
of strategic development to make complex molecule.
And the idea here is to combine enzymatic transformations
with other state-of-the-art methods in chemical synthesis.
For the enzymatic reaction,
we continue to focus on the use of enzymatic oxidation
because of the advantages that I described before.
And we believe that if we can combine this
with other imaging methods in organic chemistry,
such as photochemistry or electrochemistry
or hydrogen atom transfer-based chemistry,
we'll be able to come up
with highly unusual, but powerful connection
to streamline access to complex molecules.
Now, combining disparate elements is quite common
in the creative industries such as music or architecture.
And if you look at synthesis as a creative endeavor,
and if our goal is to make molecules to better human health,
I think we should not be so rigid in our approach
to make molecules.
And typically, in our work,
we start with discovering new biocatalyst
for such oxidation reaction.
And when necessary, we will perform enzyme engineering
to optimize the activity of this enzyme
and once we figure out what the enzymes can do,
we can then start thinking about their application
in chemoenzymatic synthesis.
I'm gonna show some vignettes of this idea.
Now, remember this idea that I had to shelf for my postdoc?
I actually was able to get back to it
in my independent career.
And this was done by leveraging
prior biosynthetic insights
in the lab of my colleague, Professor Ben Shen.
Here we were able to repurpose enzymes
from the platensimycin biosynthesis
for selective seeding and beading oxidation
on encoding structure.
And the enzymes here are PtmO5 and PtmO6.
And in parallel,
we were able to engineer a P-450 enzyme called MERO1
that can catalyze selective A ring oxidation.
And by using this technology in combination
with chemical oxidation,
we were able to convert stevioside
to more valuable and medicinally relevant terpenoids.
We also showed that we can use
the newly introduced hydroxyl group
for other types of reactions.
So, for example, we can submit the alcohol product
to fit in with a strong acid
and this affect carbocationic rearrangement
to convert an ent-beyerane structure
to the ent-trachylobane family.
And then we can submit the minimally oxidized
ent-trachylobane structure for the same type
of enzymatic oxidations
to quickly convert that to mitrephorone C.
We also showed that we can combine
enzymatic oxidation with radical-based transformations.
The idea here is to oxidize commercial terpenes,
such as sclareolide or sclareol
that contain certain substructures that are prevalent
in a lot of more complex terpenes.
And then we will use existing functional group
on this commercial terpenes to build
for the complexity.
And in this case, we elected
to use radical-based transformation and by doing so,
we were able to synthesize eight complex terpenes
with pretty diverse structural architectures.
All in all,
we have been able to synthesize more than 15 terpenes
in our lab to the application of such strategy,
and we've been able to do so in a pretty concise fashion.
And I think this really speaks to the power
of being able to harness the unique reactivity profile
of enzymatic transformation,
as well as modern chemical methodologies.
So in the past 12 minutes or so,
(indistinct) few several research areas in my lab
in the area of biocatalyst discovery
and chemoenzymatic synthesis.
And I hope to have convinced you on the benefits
of combining enzymatic reactions
for reactions are challenging to do
using traditional chemical methods,
and combine it with other emerging techniques
in organic chemistry to streamline access
to complex molecules.
And we can also use this combination
for further medicinal chemistry discovery,
as illustrated by our optimization
of the cepafungin scaffold.
And as scientists,
I think we are defined by our legacy
and I would be really happy if this talk
inspired more people to incorporate enzymatic methods
in their synthetic work.
So with that, I'd like to conclude,
and I would like to thank all the various lab members
that have made this work possible.
I've highlighted their contribution along the way.
I would like to thank them all
for their hard work and creativity.
It's been a joy to work
with all these highly talented people.
I'd like to thank collaborators,
especially Professor Ben Shen and Professor Alex Adibekian.
I would like to thank funding from NIH and NSF.
I would like to thank you all for your attention.
Thank you so much, Hans.
I agree with you that organic synthesis
is an artistic endeavor.
I think we have time for one question.
I'm gonna ask this one from Chao Wang who asks,
is there a way to screen a library of enzymes
for a specific transformation?
Yeah, certainly you can envision screening in
96-well plate.
I think the biggest challenge is to identify
an efficient analytical technique to identify hits.
And typically we still rely on LC-MS assays,
so it's pretty crude,
but it's more reliable for identifying hits.
All right, thank you so much, Hans.
(gentle music)
